abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile focuses on
            modernizing health care in Armenia. During the last two
            decades, Armenia faced enormous economic difficulties and
            crisis in social spheres, including the health care system.
            The main challenge in Armenia’s health system was to ensure
            better access of the population to quality health services.
            The Health System Modernization (HSM) Project was designed
            to improve the organization of the country’s health care
            system so as to provide more accessible, quality and
            sustainable health care services to the population. The HSM
            Project has helped increase the geographical and financial
            access of Armenia’s most vulnerable population to quality
            basic health services through infrastructure development,
            provision of modern equipment to health facilities in rural
            areas, and the upgrading of Primary Health Care (PHC)
            service providers’ knowledge and skills. About 80 percent of
            the country’s population was covered by retrained family
            medicine providers. Turning the principal hospital networks
            in the country’s regions into a high quality health care
            provider’s network, accompanied by a development of the PHC
            infrastructure in rural areas, reoriented regional patient
            flows from the capital city of Yerevan to the local health facilities.
